channel.title: ROP on malware.boutique
channel.description: Recent content in ROP on malware.boutique

item.title: CircleCityCon 2021: weirdrop
item.description: I didn’t participate in the CTF, but I noticed that there is no writeup for this challenge, so I decided to address that. :D You can find the exploit source here . Exploitable Service We get an exploitable service binary. [joey@gibson] file weird-rop weird-rop: ELF 64-bit LSB executable, x86-64, version 1 (SYSV), statically linked, BuildID[sha1]=2876651ce7257d4153ee90b05f0b1a2b29f25700, not stripped Neato! We got a 64-bit ELF. The binary is statically compiled and not stripped, making reversing and exploitation much easier for us.

item.title: BSIDES SF 2021: ropme
item.description: I didn’t really participate in the ctf, but I found this challenge to be interesting and since not many teams solved it/posted writeups I decided to post my solution. It’s probably not the most elegant - if you solved it in a different way I’d love to hear about it. The exploit source can be found here. In this writeup, I’m assuming you have a basic understanding of x86 architecture, return oriented programming, and the Linux API.
